file_metadata.title: Asymmetric expression of Syndecan-2 in early chick embryogenesis

chunks.text: Chicken Syndecan-2 (cSyndecan-2), a heparan sulfate proteoglycan, plays a role in left-right patterning in frog embryos, but its role in other species' asymmetry has not been explored. This study investigates cSyndecan-2 expression in chick embryos during early development to understand its potential involvement in left-right asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the expression of cSyndecan-2 in chick embryos to understand its role in left-right asymmetry.

chunks.text: cSyndecan-2 is expressed in the primitive streak between stages 1 and 3, localizing to the rostral and caudal tips at stage 4.  Asymmetric expression is observed on the right side of Hensen's node from stages 5 to 7.  Later, expression appears in somites and neural folds, persisting in the neural tube while disappearing from somites by stage 11.  This study reveals a novel asymmetric transcript in chick embryos, suggesting that cSyndecan-2 asymmetry occurs at the mRNA level, unlike the protein-level asymmetry observed in Xenopus.
chunks.chunk_summary: cSyndecan-2 exhibits dynamic and asymmetric expression patterns during early chick development, notably in the primitive streak, Hensen's node, somites, and neural tube.

chunks.text: Syndecans, transmembrane heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs), are crucial for development. Syndecan-2 is involved in left-right patterning in Xenopus, acting as a Vg1 cofactor and regulating Vg1-related signals, essential for early embryogenesis.  This study investigates Syndecan-2 expression in chick embryos to address the evolutionary divergence of asymmetry mechanisms across species.
chunks.chunk_summary: Syndecan-2's role in left-right patterning is investigated in chick embryos to understand the evolution of asymmetry mechanisms.

chunks.text: cSyndecan-2 is weakly expressed at the posterior margin at stage 0, then in the primitive streak base at stage 1, and throughout the streak until stage 3, specifically in the mesendodermal layer. At stage 4, expression is symmetrical at Hensen's node and the primitive streak base.  Asymmetric expression on the right side of the node appears at stages 5 and 6, confirmed by sectioning, and persists until stage 7, disappearing by stage 8.
chunks.chunk_summary: cSyndecan-2 expression shifts from the primitive streak to become asymmetrically localized at Hensen's node during early chick development.

chunks.text: At stage 7, cSyndecan-2 expression coincides with the first somite. Between stages 8 and 11, expression is observed in somites and neural folds, specifically within the mesoderm layer of the folds. By stage 12, strong expression is seen in the neural tube and weaker expression in the lateral plate mesoderm.  Within the neural tube, expression is strong, and it is also present in central notochord cells.
chunks.topic: cSyndecan-2 expression in somites and neural tube
chunks.chunk_summary: cSyndecan-2 expression appears in somites and neural folds, becoming prominent in the neural tube and central notochord cells.

chunks.text: By stage 15, neural tube expression weakens, with no expression in the heart or other tissues. Disappearance of the transcript begins dorsally in the neural tube, but persists ventrally and in the notochord. Expression progressively weakens; by stage 18, only the lens of the eye shows strong expression. No specific staining is observed after stage 23.
chunks.chunk_summary: cSyndecan-2 expression in the neural tube diminishes over time, with persistent expression only in the eye lens by later stages.

chunks.text: This study identifies a transcriptional-level asymmetry of chick Syndecan-2 during late gastrulation. This finding aligns with other left-right asymmetry pathways that operate at the protein level in Xenopus but at the mRNA level in chick.
chunks.chunk_summary: Chick Syndecan-2 exhibits asymmetry at the mRNA level, contrasting with the protein-level asymmetry seen in Xenopus.

chunks.text: The full-length cSyndecan-2 sequence (606 bases) was amplified from stage 23 chicken embryo RNA using primers based on Gene Bank information (accession number: AF508229). The sequence was cloned into pBluescript SK(+), linearized, and transcribed with T3 polymerase to generate a DIG-labeled antisense transcript for in situ hybridization following standard protocols. Chick stages are according to Hamburger and Hamilton (1992).
chunks.chunk_summary: Standard molecular biology techniques were used to clone cSyndecan-2 and perform in situ hybridization on chick embryos.
